intro: Juncus arizonicus var. curtiflorus, commonly known as the Arizona rush, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It is a member of the Juncaceae family and is characterized by its dense, grass-like foliage and spike-like inflorescences. The plant typically grows in wetland habitats, such as marshes and riparian zones, where it thrives in moist to wet soil conditions. Its flowers are small and inconspicuous, often arranged in clusters at the tips of its stems. This variety is distinguished by its shorter, more compact flower clusters compared to other varieties within the Juncus arizonicus species.
